Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A mandatory pre-shift briefing on new operational procedures is about to start.
Story: I glance at my phone as I button up my uniform, my partner’s text lighting up the screen: “Can you talk? I had a terrible day.” I can almost hear the tremor in her voice, see the way her shoulders slump when she’s upset. I want to be there, to listen, to reassure her that she’s more than her boss’s words. But the clock on the wall is relentless. In ten minutes, the pre-shift briefing starts—mandatory, no exceptions. New procedures are being rolled out, and missing the details could mean risking passenger safety or even my job. My phone buzzes again, her name flashing insistently. I feel the weight of her need, the expectation that I’ll be her anchor. At the same time, the responsibility of hundreds of commuters presses on me, the unspoken demand to be focused, alert, professional. My heart aches with the pull in both directions, torn between the person I love and the duty I can’t ignore. I stand frozen, phone in hand, the seconds ticking by, caught in the impossible space between two worlds.
